SATURDAY
ON 48 HOURSHere's a note from Bill Lagattuta on Saturday's 48 
      Hours Mystery, NIGHTMARE IN NAPA: "Our 
      story this week sounds a lot like the plot of one of those Hollywood 
      slasher flicks. But this story really happened. Two young women viciously 
      murdered in their home by an unknown attacker with a knife who disappeared 
      into the night. And it happened on Halloween. The scene of the crime was 
      the beautiful Napa Valley, America's premiere wine country in California. 
      That made the crime seem even more brutal because killings like that are 
      unheard of in Napa. As we covered the story of the crime three years ago, 
      the killer was still at large and the chance of finding him began to 
      dwindle with each passing month. The families grew frustrated as police 
      seemed unable to turn up new evidence or find suspects. And then it 
      happened... an ending to this story almost a year to the month of the 
      murders. I won't spoil it... the accused killer is someone no one 
      suspected. I hope you'll join us on Saturday night." - Bill 
      Lagattuta 48 Hours Mystery airs Saturdays at 
      10pmET/PT FOR MORE ON THIS STORY, WHY NOT READ THE 
      BOOK? 48 Hours Mystery, Nightmare in 
      Napa is now available in bookstores and online at 
      Amazon.com Click Here. This is the first in a brand 
      new series of true crime books published by Simon and Schuster, Pocket 
      Books. Here's more from 48 Hours 
      producer and author Paul LaRosa. "Nightmare in Napa 
      is the first in a series of true crime books based on the broadcasts of 
      CBS News' 48 Hours Mystery. It is the 
      chilling story of what happened to two women in a house in Napa, 
      California on Halloween night, 2004. 48 Hours 
      Mystery already had produced an hour on the story when Executive 
      Producer Susan Zirinsky and Executive Editor Al Briganti 
      hatched the idea to do a series of true crime books. They asked me to get 
      involved and write the first book because I had then recently published a 
      true crime book of my own called Tacoma Confidential. I 
      began reviewing all the tapes from the Napa broadcast and, as always, 
      there were a lot. That's something most viewers do not realize. In 
      producing any hour for 48 Hours Mystery, producers typically 
      will supervise the videotaping of more than one hundred hours of 
      interviews and other material. All of those hours are edited down to make 
      a compelling, fast-moving, one-hour broadcast for prime-time television. 
      This should give you an idea of the wealth and breadth of material we 
      compile for each broadcast. Because of time restrictions, a lot of 
      material never makes it onto the air. So much is left out that, well, you 
      could write a book, and that's just what we're going to do in this series. 
      Just under three-hundred, thirty-minute tapes existed for the 
      first hour. I went through a good portion of them but decided I had to go 
      to Napa and meet the principals and get a feel for the town and the Napa 
      Valley. So that's what I did. I got to meet, have lunch with or email many 
      of those involved with the story. In some cases, I did original reporting. 
      The original hour ended with the arrest of the murderer but now the case 
      had to wind its way through the courts. I followed it every step of the 
      way, culminating with the dramatic sentencing of the defendant in January, 
      2007. Along the way, I got a real sense for the lives of the two 
      murder victims: Adriane Insogna and Leslie Mazzara, and I hope that I've 
      been true to their memories in the book. They were both special young 
      women whose families are heartbroken by their loss. In many ways, the most 
      surprising aspect of the story is not the murder itself but the identity 
      of the murderer and his reasons for doing what he did. To buy the 
      book: Click Here I can't wait until you 
      read it and please send along your comments. My email is PLR@CBSNEWS.COM 
      or look at my website: PaulLaRosa.com Click Here." Thanks, Paul 
      LaRosa If you would like more information on any of these stories 
      or the broadcast, please click on the following address and e-mail us at: 
      48hours@cbsnews.com 

TONIGHT ON THE CBS EVENING NEWSHere's an 
      early look at what we are working on for tonight's broadcast of the CBS 
      EVENING NEWS from Anchor and Managing Editor, Katie Couric...
Hi everyone, On the anniversary of the Columbine school 
      massacre, it is a day of complex mourning. Vigils and moments of silence 
      across the country remembered the lives of the 32 victims of Monday’s 
      tragedy at Virginia Tech. Sharyn Alfonsi will have the story of 
      this day of mourning. But the observances were haunted by ghosts of what 
      the similar tragedy eight years ago at Columbine high School in Littleton, 
      Colorado. Bill Whitaker will bring you this story. Our 
      chief investigative correspondent Armen Keteyian will continue 
      coverage of how Seung-Hui Cho obtained his weapons. One day after 
      embattled Attorney General Alberto Gonzales attempted to explain the 
      firings of eight federal prosecutors to a Senate panel, the White House 
      stepped up to back him. Has he done a “fantastic job” as a spokesperson 
      said today, or is he about to lose his job? Jim Axelrod will have 
      the latest. And Nancy Cordes will report on the 
      investigation into the pet food contamination scare. The FDA suggests that 
      much of the recalled pet food may have been intentionally spiked with an 
      industrial chemical that would boost their protein content. We’ll take a 
      closer look. Meanwhile, the stock market is racing toward a new 
      milestone – thanks to strong earnings reports from Internet superstar 
      Google Inc. Anthony Mason will have more. Finally, Steve 
      Hartman will have a story about a warmhearted man who’s helping get 
      homeless people off the street. He’s drastically improved the lives of 
      many people. How? With massive quantities of hot dogs – really. Join us 
      for his story. I hope you have a wonderful weekend. 
      Katie For more on two of the stories noted 
      above, please click on the following links: Nation Grieves 
      With Virginia Tech Click Here FDA Mulls Motive In 
      Pet Food Case Click Here And here's a look at 
      one of the stories we are working on for Monday's broadcast of the CBS 
      EVENING NEWS: After Imus, We'll tell you what African 
      Americans think about hate speech used in rap and hip hop. You'll be 
      surprised at who its most ardent fans are. So that story and MUCH more, 
      Monday night on the CBS EVENING NEWS. If you would like more 
      information on any of these stories or the broadcast, please click on the 
      following address and e-mail us: evening@cbsnews.com 
      

TONIGHT ON DAVID 
      LETTERMANDave chats with actress Jessica 
      Biel AND This American Life host/producer Ira Glass... Plus, 
      musical guest Regina Spektor! 

TOMORROW ON THE SATURDAY EARLY SHOWTracy 
      Smith and Debbye Turner anchor The Saturday Early 
      Show from New York. Kelly Wallace will 
      anchor from Blacksburg, VA. Ira Joe Fisher will bring us the 
      weather. Along with the top news of the 
      day, we will also have the following stories: HEALTHWATCH – 
      CHOCOLATE: Several recent studies have found that chocolate and/or 
      cocoa actually have health benefits. German researchers found that dark 
      chocolate and other cocoa-rich foods lower blood pressure more effectively 
      than green or black tea. It has also been found to help muscles recover 
      from exercise, improve the skin, and boost memory. We’ll turn to Health 
      Magazine Senior Food and Nutrition Editor Frances Largeman-Roth for 
      more on the benefits of chocolate. SATURDAY SPOTLIGHT: Ride 
      for Mobility is a cross-country bike ride that raises money for the Free 
      Wheelchair Mission, a mission that aims to buy 15,000 wheelchairs for 
      physically disabled people in developing countries. We will hear details 
      about this program from the co-founders of Ride for Mobility, Dr. Mike 
      Bayer and Don Schoendorfer. Plus, they will begin their 3,000-mile journey 
      along with a team of cyclists from our plaza! MONEY MATTERS - 
      FOR SALE BY OWNER: More and more homeowners are skipping hiring a real 
      estate broker and selling their properties themselves. Is cutting this 
      cost worth it in the end? Financial adviser Ray Martin will explain 
      the advantages and potential pitfalls of selling your home without a real 
      estate broker as well as provide some advice for those determined to do it 
      themselves. SUMMERIZING YOUR PET: Summer is near, and it is 
      a good idea to think about how to protect your pets from warm-weather 
      health hazards. Veterinarian Ann Hohenhaus, Chairman of Medicine for the 
      Animal Medical Center in NY, will join us on our plaza with tips on how to 
      protect your pets from common summer problems like ticks and fleas, 
      household dangers, and too much sun or heat. CHEF ON A 
      SHOESTRING: Food Network personality Guy Fieri is launching a new 
      series, Diners, Drive-Ins & Dives. In his new show, Fieri shows 
      how anyone can cook up a classic American meal with a unique twist. He'll 
      join us in our Chef on a Shoestring to make an updated dinner 
      classic on our budget of $40. SECOND CUP CAFÉ: Augustana is 
      a folk/rock band out of San Diego, CA. This band, reminiscent of Matchbox 
      20 and Counting Crows, has gained recent success with catchy tunes like 
      “Boston” and “Stars and Boulevards.” Augustana will perform their 
      heartfelt songs from their latest album, All the Stars and 
      Boulevards, in our Second Cup Café. To look for our 
      fabulous recipes... Click Here If you would like more 
      information on any of these stories or the broadcast, please click on the 
      following address and e-mail us: sat@cbsnews.com 
      

HERE'S WHAT WE HAVE PLANNED FOR SUNDAY 
      MORNINGCHARLES OSGOOD ANCHORS 
      FROM NEW YORK VIRGINIA TECH: After a week of watching and 
      analyzing every nuance of the horrific events at Virginia Tech, what have 
      we learned? As a nation, we've been in this situation before and it seems 
      to be playing out in a very similar manner. So are we all-talk or are we 
      accomplishing something? If so, what? After all, at the bottom of every 
      report and every debate is the desire for everyone to be safe all the 
      time. Is that possible? And what are we willing to give up in order to 
      make that possible? What factors are contributing to these shootings? And 
      is there something inherently American about them? Correspondent Martha 
      Teichner looks for answers on Sunday Morning. JOEL GREY: Joel Grey is one of just a handful of 
      actors to win an Oscar and a Tony for the same role. He was 
      the Emcee in Cabaret, and went on to star on stage, film and television. 
      But it turns out Grey is as comfortable behind a camera as in front of 
      one. At the age of 75, he's developed a second career as a photographer. 
      In this Sunday Morning Profile, 
      Correspondent Rita Braver talks with Grey about his new career, and 
      his lifetime in show business. http://www.joelgreyphotographer.com 
      Click 
      Here http://www.steidlville.com Click Here ART HISTORY: Correspondent Mark Phillips 
      reports on a rare exhibit at the British Museum that provides a snapshot 
      of history. Painted in 1518 by one of the first English settlers, these 
      are the first images of Native Americans. RACHEL CARSON: 
      Mild-mannered scientist and writer Rachel Carson was an unlikely activist, 
      but her book, Silent Spring, is credited with starting the 
      environmental movement. Her legacy can be seen in the formation of the 
      Environmental Protection Agency, which in 1972 banned the DDT pesticide in 
      this country, and can be found in today's debates over global warming, 
      clean energy, and organic food. Correspondent Thalia Assuras 
      reports. LEE IACOCCA: Correspondent Anthony Mason 
      talks to Lee Iacocca about his new book, Where Have All the Leaders 
      Gone? PLASTIC BAGS: When you head to the grocery story, 
      chances are you come out with a whole car load of plastic bags. They've 
      become so commonplace in America that discarded bags are taking up a lot 
      of room in our nation's landfills... and increasingly they've become an 
      environmental concern. One U.S. city recently decided to take on this 
      growing problem with an all-out ban on plastic grocery bags. John 
      Blackstone reports. If you would like more information on any 
      of these stories or the broadcast, please click on the following address 
      and e-mail us: sundays@cbsnews.com 

SUNDAY ON FACE THE 
      NATION Bob Schieffer moderates...CBS News’ Face the 
      Nation this week is going to focus on the two 
      big stories of the week: the Virginia Tech shootings and the testimony of 
      U.S. Attorney General Alberto Gonzales. Could the rampage at Virginia Tech 
      have been avoided? Would more or fewer gun laws make a difference? And 
      what is the role of colleges in situations like this? All questions for 
      gun control advocates Jim and Sarah Brady and former FBI profiler Gregg 
      McCrary. We'll also talk with the Chairman of the Senate Judiciary 
      Committee, Patrick Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, about whether he thought 
      Attorney General Gonzales helped or hurt himself with his testimony in 
      Congress about the firing of U.S. attorneys. All of this on this week’s 
      Face the Nation with Bob 
      Schieffer. And there will be, as always, a final word. 

SUNDAY ON 60 MINUTESMIND OF AN 
      ASSASSIN: Few people know more about the minds of assassins than 
      those protecting the president of the U.S. Secret Service intelligence 
      officers compare their research to the characteristics of the Virginia 
      Tech shooter. Scott Pelley reports. LIFE IN BAGHDAD: 
      Bombs, shootings and long gas lines are some of the obstacles that 
      residents of Iraq's capital city must deal with daily to survive. Lara 
      Logan reports. STOP SNITCHIN': Anderson Cooper reports 
      on how the hip-hop culture's message not to cooperate with the police in 
      any way has undermined efforts to solve murders across the country. 

MONDAY MORNING ON THE 
      EARLY SHOWHarry Smith, Hannah 
      Storm, Julie Chen and Russ Mitchell anchor THE 
      EARLY SHOW from New York. Dave Price 
      will bring us the weather. Along with the top news of the day, 
      we will also have the following stories: ARE YOU AT RISK?: 
      TRIGGER MORTGAGES: A warning to anyone who is applying for or has a 
      mortgage: Whether you know it or not, your personal and financial 
      information could be getting distributed to hundreds of strangers. It can 
      happen the very night you apply for that loan. CBS News Correspondent 
      Mark Strassmann will join us with the story of a growing trend that 
      is taking home buyers by surprise. PERFECT PARENTING: CHOOSING 
      A SUMMER CAMP: As temperatures heat up, swimming pools and summer camp 
      are not far away. But how can you select a camp for your child that is 
      instructive, yet still retains that essence of summertime fun? Monday 
      morning, we'll speak with the folks from KIWI magazine to get their 
      advice before you pack your kids lunches and wave goodbye to those dog 
      days of summer. SIGOURNEY WEAVER ON THE TV SET: 
      People say that Hollywood doesn't care about veteran actresses, but don't 
      say that to Sigourney Weaver. Three decades after her movie career began, 
      Weaver is busier than ever. This month alone, she has two very different 
      films opening. One of those films is The TV Set, in which Weaver 
      plays Lenny, the brash, headstrong president of PDN, who must approve all 
      creative decisions of the network. The film is a smart, engaging comedy 
      about the trials and tribulations of getting a television pilot off the 
      ground. Co-starring David Duchovny, the film is a satirical look at the 
      entertainment industry from the eyes of those who work within it. Monday 
      morning, we will speak with Sigourney Weaver about her latest big screen 
      attraction. FITNESS: GETTING IN SHAPE FOR SUMMER: If you 
      have been a couch potato all winter long, then there has never been a 
      better time to kick it into high gear. Revving up your exercise routine is 
      a sure-fire way to get in shape and get those trouble spots tight and 
      toned in no time. Now, it's easy. With fitness expert Minna Lessig's new 
      workout DVD, Tank Top Arms, Bikini Belly, Boy Shorts Bottom. Monday 
      morning, Minna will join us to demonstrate all the latest workout moves 
      that are sure to get your heart pumping! If you would like more 
      information on any of these stories or the broadcast, please click on the 
      following address and e-mail us: earlyshow@cbs.com
